articles.headline: Senators Take Auto Agency to Task Over G.M. Recall
articles.snippet: The top official from the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration faced withering criticism over the agency’s failure to detect a deadly ignition defect in G.M. cars.
articles.abstract: The top official from the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration faced withering criticism over the agency’s failure to detect a deadly ignition defect in G.M. cars.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The nation’s top auto regulator faced withering criticism across Capitol Hill on Tuesday over its failure to identify a deadly defect in General Motors cars — even as its top official tried again and again to shift the blame back to the automaker.
articles.byline: By Hilary Stout and Aaron M. Kessler

articles.headline: Globalization Is in Retreat? Not So Fast
articles.snippet: While some observers see a “reshoring” of global manufacturing to the United States, the globalization trend is far from over.
articles.abstract: While some observers see a “reshoring” of global manufacturing to the United States, the globalization trend is far from over.
articles.lead_paragraph: Not long ago, executives at the Dutch multinational Royal DSM, a globe-girdling maker of nutritional supplements and high-tech materials, used to require a battery of internal studies to decide where to do a deal or locate a new manufacturing plant.

articles.headline: Obama Presses Leaders to Speed Ebola Response
articles.snippet: President Obama, warning that the disease could take hundreds of thousands of lives, called on other nations to help the United States as it leads the fight.
articles.abstract: President Obama, warning that the disease could take hundreds of thousands of lives, called on other nations to help the United States as it leads the fight.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — President Obama on Tuesday challenged world powers to accelerate the global response to the Ebola outbreak that is ravaging West Africa, warning that unless health care workers, medical equipment and treatment centers were swiftly deployed, the disease could take hundreds of thousands of lives.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper and Sheri Fink

articles.headline: Independence Movement’s Energy Wager Could Prove Risky for Scotland
articles.snippet: Ownership of North Sea energy assets, and control of the taxes they produce, have been a rallying cry for nationalists — but rising costs and fluctuating prices make projecting revenues difficult.
articles.abstract: Ownership of North Sea energy assets, and control of the taxes they produce, have been a rallying cry for nationalists — but rising costs and fluctuating prices make projecting revenues difficult.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Scottish nationalists have long argued that being governed from London has deprived their country of its fair share of the wealth from Britain’s oil and natural gas fields, which mostly lie in North Sea waters off their shores.

articles.headline: CD-Loving Japan Resists Move to Online Music
articles.snippet: Japan may be a perennial early adopter of technologies, but its attachment to the CD puts it sharply at odds with the rest of the global music industry.
articles.abstract: Japan may be a perennial early adopter of technologies, but its attachment to the CD puts it sharply at odds with the rest of the global music industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Around the world, the music business has shifted toward downloads and streaming. But in Japan, the compact disc is still king.

articles.headline: Review and Video: With Big New iPhones, It’s What’s Inside That Counts
articles.snippet: The slim new iPhone 6 and 6 Plus aren’t a slam-dunk, but they work well, as users expect from Apple products.
articles.abstract: The slim new iPhone 6 and 6 Plus aren’t a slam-dunk, but they work well, as users expect from Apple products.

articles.headline: Shiite Militias Pose Challenge for U.S. in Iraq
articles.snippet: The de facto coalition of militias, the United States and the Iraqi government against the Islamic State shows little promise for stability.
articles.abstract: The de facto coalition of militias, the United States and the Iraqi government against the Islamic State shows little promise for stability.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Militia justice is simple, the fighters explained.

articles.headline: Report Cites Forced Labor in Malaysia’s Electronics Industry
articles.snippet: About a third of the 200,000 migrant workers in Malaysia’s thriving electronics industry are employed in forced labor conditions, according to Verité, a factory monitoring group.
articles.abstract: About a third of the 200,000 migrant workers in Malaysia’s thriving electronics industry are employed in forced labor conditions, according to Verité, a factory monitoring group.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nearly one in three migrant workers in Malaysia’s thriving electronics industry toils under forced labor conditions, essentially trapped in the job, a factory monitoring group found in a report issued on Wednesday.
